descriptions.title: An Overview of Thousand-Household Districts in the Tibetan Empire
descriptions.content:
A Thousand-household District (stong sde) is a military and administrative division of Imperial Tibet during the eighth and ninth centuries. The thousand-household districts were administered by larger administrative units called "horns" (ru). Originally all horns didn't have the same number of thousand-household districts, but in 744 a territorial reorganisation balanced the disparities between horns. This is why the affiliation of some of the thousand-household districts changed horn-affiliation in 744.

The name is derived from it being a district supposed to provide a regiment of one thousand soldiers, or alternatively, that it is a district of one thousand households. Either way, each household was supposed to provide one solidier for the imperial army.
